Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 39579  
December 2005 
 
 
 
Technical Assistance 
Strengthening Economic and Financial Monitoring in 
Selected ASEAN+3 Countries
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
ASEAN+3  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations plus People’s 
Republic of China, Japan and Republic of Korea 
ASP  –  ASEAN Surveillance Process 
EWS  –  early warning system 
FMP  –  Finance Ministers’ Process 
IMF  –  International Monetary Fund 
Lao PDR  –  Lao People's Democratic Republic 
NSU  –  national surveillance unit 
OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation 
Subtheme  –  Promoting macroeconomic stability 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
G. Capannelli, Senior Economist, Office of Regional Economic Integration.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At a regional workshop for officials of ministries of finance and central banks of members 
of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus Japan, Republic of Korea, and 
People’s Republic of China (PRC)─or ASEAN+3 countries─organized in April 2005 in Jakarta,1 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) was requested to continue its support for capacity building 
of national surveillance units (NSUs) and similar government agencies provided under two 
phases of an existing regional technical assistance (TA) project, which is due for completion by 
the end of 2005.2 ADB was also requested to support regional meetings of NSUs and similar 
government agencies in the ministries of finance and central banks through regional workshops 
aimed at discussing technical issues, such as financial vulnerability assessment, to be included 
in the economic surveillance reports and other economic and financial reports tabled at the 
ASEAN and ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers’ and Deputies’ meetings. Such effort is seen as an 
important way to strengthen the economic review and policy dialogue process among ASEAN+3 
countries  and  boost  regional  economic  cooperation  and  integration.  During  the  Jakarta 
workshop, ADB was also asked to extend to Malaysia and the PRC assistance on economic 
and  financial  monitoring  similar  to  that  provided  to  Cambodia,  Indonesia,  Lao  People’s 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam through their NSUs. A 
request to include support for creating libraries on financial surveillance within NSUs and similar 
agencies was also made. 
 
2.  During the first half of 2005, fact-finding missions were fielded to the aforementioned 
countries and intensive consultation was conducted with relevant agencies, including ministries 
of finance, central banks, national statistics offices, and economic research centers. A general 
agreement was reached to start a new phase of ADB assistance by including all eight countries 
in one project. The terms and conditions of participation by Malaysia and the PRC in the project 
were  included  in  aide  memoires  prepared  in  close  coordination  with  the  respective 
administrations during fact-finding. This paper reflects the objectives, scope, cost estimates, 
financing plans, and implementation arrangements discussed with the concerned government 
agencies during fact-finding.3 The design and monitoring framework is attached as Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  After the Asian financial crisis of 1997, the finance ministers of ASEAN+3 countries 
established a process of economic review and policy dialogue among themselves to discuss 
issues of mutual interest, including concrete efforts to prevent crises from recurring through a 
 
                                                 
1  Workshop  on  Quantitative  Methods  for  Economic  and  Financial  Monitoring  and  Strengthening  of  National 
Surveillance Units in East Asia, jointly-organized by ADB-ASEAN Secretariat-Ministry of Finance, Indonesia, in 
Jakarta on 25–26 April 2005. 
2  Assistance was initially provided for Indonesia, Philippines, and Thailand under ADB. 1999. Technical Assistance 
for Capacity Building of Ministries of Finance of Selected DMCs for the ASEAN Surveillance Process. Manila (TA 
5879-REG, for $500,000, approved on 16 December). Subsequently, under phase II of the project, assistance was 
extended to Cambodia, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, and Viet Nam under ADB; ADB. 2000. Technical 
Assistance for Capacity Building of Ministries of Finance of Selected DMCs for the ASEAN Surveillance Process 
(Phase II), Manila (TA 5965–REG, for $300,000, approved on December), and continued to Indonesia, Philippines, 
and Thailand; ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building of Ministries of Finance in Selected DMCs for 
the ASEAN Surveillance Process (Part 2), Manila (TA 6012–REG, for $300,000, approved on December).  
3  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 12 September 2005.

2   
shared approach to regional economic and financial monitoring.4 The Finance Ministers of 
ASEAN+3 countries requested ADB to strengthen the capacity of their national and regional 
institutions involved in this process, and ADB responded with a three-pronged capacity-building 
effort by (i) organizing a training course on regional economic and financial monitoring for 
ministries of finance and central bank officials;5 (ii) supporting the establishment of NSUs in 
Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam; and (iii) strengthening the 
capacity of the ASEAN Secretariat. 6  
 
4.  While the third activity has been successfully concluded, the two others continue to be 
an important focus of ADB’s support to strengthen ASEAN+3 countries’ capacity to monitor their 
financial vulnerabilities. Under the second activity, in particular, the six existing NSUs have 
received ADB assistance through (i) consulting services, (ii) equipment, (iii) technical training, 
and (iv) workshops. Through such support, the NSUs were able to enhance the skills of their 
staff in preparing surveillance reports and filling in a data template for economic and financial 
indicators currently used by the ASEAN Secretariat to gather data from its members.7  
 
5.  In parallel with this capacity-building effort, ADB has also supported regional economic 
and financial monitoring activities among ASEAN+3 countries through the establishment of an 
early warning system (EWS) software to assess financial vulnerabilities and provide insights in 
preventing  financial  crises.  For  this  purpose,  two  technical  assistance  (TA)  projects  were 
approved: one to develop a regional EWS prototype model, and another one to develop a 
windows-based EWS software and disseminate it to NSUs and similar agencies in the ministries 
of finance and central banks of ASEAN+3 countries.8 The dissemination process, including 
                                                 
4 ASEAN finance ministers established the ASEAN Surveillance Process (ASP) in February 1998, and the finance 
ministers of ASEAN countries plus Japan, Republic of Korea, and PRC established the ASEAN+3 Finance 
Ministers’ Process in November 1999. Under the ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers Process (ASEAN+3 FMP), ministers 
of finance meet once a year and their deputies twice a year to discuss and review regional economic and financial 
developments, including issues of surveillance. The ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers Process has four components: 
(i) Economic Review and Policy Dialogue, (ii) the Chiang Mai Initiative, (iii) the Asian Bond Market Initiative, and 
(iv) the ASEAN+3 Research Group. 
5  One hundred forty-three midlevel officials have already completed a training course on regional economic and 
financial monitoring, including a special part on early warning systems (EWS), offered semiannually at ADB 
headquarters. Assistance has been provided under phases I–IV of the regional TA. ADB. 1998. Technical 
Assistance for Technical Training and Capacity Building in Support of the ASEAN Economic Surveillance Process. 
Manila (TA 5827-REG, for $707,000, approved on December); ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for Technical 
Training and Capacity Building in Support of the ASEAN Economic Surveillance Process, Phase II. Manila (TA 
6019-REG, for $200,000, approved on December); ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for Technical Training and 
Capacity Building in Support of the ASEAN Economic Surveillance Process, Phase III. Manila (TA 6071-REG, for 
$300,000, approved on December); ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for Technical Training and Capacity Building 
in Support of the ASEAN Surveillance Process, Phase IV. Manila (TA 6201-REG, for $310,000, approved on 
November). 
6  Assistance was provided under ADB. 1998. Technical Assistance for Capacity building for the ASEAN Surveillance 
Coordination Unit and Technical Support for the ASP. Manila (TA 5870-REG, for $980,000, approved on 24 
December).  
7 Regional economic and financial monitoring conducted under the ASP and ASEAN+3 FMP presents distinguished 
features that complement global and national surveillance activities of the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Apart 
from its regional focus, surveillance activities conducted under the ASP and ASEAN+3 FMP do not follow the 
prescriptive approach associated with the IMF’s Article IV consultation but a comparatively informal process based 
on a peer review of economic circumstances; they rather focus on facilitating information exchange, raising issues 
for discussion among members, and exploring alternative solutions, as new challenges arise to regional economic 
development and financial stability.  
8 Respectively, ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for An ASEAN+3 Framework for the Development of Early Warning 
Systems, (TA 5986–REG: for $150,000, approved in July); ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building 
for Implementing Early Warning Systems in ASEAN+3 Countries, Manila (TA 6070–REG  for $300,000, approved 
in December).

3
installation of and training on the software─named Vulnerability Indicators and Early Warning 
System (VIEWS)─is under way and is expected to be completed by the first half of 2006. 
 
6.  Two phases of a TA preceding the present one (footnote 2) have assisted the finance 
ministries of Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam by facilitating 
the establishment of NSUs and developing a self-sustaining capacity to discharge surveillance 
responsibilities.9  This  support  has  significantly  strengthened  the  quality  of  the  economic 
surveillance reports tabled at the ASEAN Finance Ministers’ as well as the ASEAN+3 Finance 
Ministers’ and Deputies’ meetings. However, because of the complexities of the issues at stake, 
the little knowledge available at the start of the process, and the high staff turnover in NSUs and 
similar agencies, it is necessary to further strengthen the capacity of the involved institutions. In 
addition to macroeconomic issues, this TA will support efforts of NSUs and similar agencies to 
incorporate more technical issues such as financial vulnerability assessment in the economic 
surveillance reports tabled at the ASEAN Finance Ministers’ and ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers’ 
and Deputies’ meetings. The current TA proposes to extend these activities also to Malaysia 
and  the  PRC,  taking  into  account  their  national  circumstances  and  considering  that  NSU 
functions can be performed by similar agencies as well. In coordination with other assistance 
projects  to  ASEAN+3  countries  for  regional  economic  and  financial  monitoring,  including 
technical  training  programs  and  development  of  the  VIEWS  software,  the  present  TA  will 
strengthen the capacity of NSUs and similar agencies to perform surveillance operations.10
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The purposes of the TA are: (i) to further strengthen institutional and technical capacities 
of NSUs and similar government agencies involved in economic and financial monitoring under 
the ASEAN Surveillance Process (ASP) and the ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers’ Process (FMP); 
and (ii) to strengthen coordination both among NSUs in the region and between NSUs and other 
national institutions—central banks, statistical offices, and others—involved in economic and 
financial  monitoring.  To  achieve  these  objectives,  the  TA  will  provide  consulting  services, 
technical training, and equipment;11 promote research activity; organize regional workshops in 
support of the ASP and the ASEAN+3 FMP; and support the creation of libraries on economic 
and financial monitoring to be located in the NSUs or similar agencies. In particular, research 
activity on surveillance-related issues, training courses, and on-the-job training conducted under 
this  TA  will  strengthen  the  participating  countries’  technical  and  institutional  capacities.  In 
addition, through coordination with other TAs such as those for development of and training on 
the EWS software and training on regional economic and financial monitoring, the TA will help 
reduce the problem of high staff turnover in NSUs and similar agencies. At the same time, the 
organization  of  regional  workshops  on  technical  issues  related  to  surveillance  will  help 
strengthen coordination both among NSUs and between NSUs and other institutions involved in 
economic and financial monitoring.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The countries to be included in this TA are Cambodia, PRC, Indonesia, Lao PDR, 
Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam. The TA will support: 
 
(i)  Training of concerned national staff from the ministries of finance, central banks, 
and other agencies on issues related to economic and financial monitoring with 
emphasis  on  the  assessment  of  financial  vulnerabilities,  EWS,  and  leading 
economic  indicators.  Training  will  be  provided  through  seminars,  workshops, 
tailor-made courses, as well as on-the-job monitoring. To the extent possible, 
training programs will be organized on a collaborative basis among participating 
developing member countries. 
(ii)  Organization of regional workshops for NSUs and similar agencies, with the aim 
of providing technical support and advice in preparing for the ASEAN Finance 
Ministers’ and  ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers’ and Deputies’ meetings. 
(iii)  Research and studies conducted by NSUs and similar agencies on economic 
and financial monitoring, including preparing national surveillance reports and 
data templates, as well as national and regional economic outlook reports, and 
creating and managing specific databases and libraries. 
 
9.  International and domestic consultants and resource persons will be engaged to design 
and  conduct  national  and  regional  workshops  on  surveillance-related  topics,  taking  into 
consideration feedback from the assessment of other related TAs and specific needs of each 
participating country. TA resources will also be used to support a variety of other capacity-
building activities including, but not limited to, participation in seminars, workshops, and training 
courses  offered  by  local  or  foreign  institutions  in  areas  related  to  economic  and  financial 
monitoring, EWS, and economic indicators. The TA will encourage collaborative and individual 
research  initiatives  by  NSUs  and  similar  agencies  and  will  support  the  publication  and 
dissemination  of  associated  outputs  through  appropriate  channels.  Initiatives  that  foster 
information exchange within and among countries will be also encouraged. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  The total estimated cost of the TA is $850,000 equivalent, of which $600,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The balance of $250,000 equivalent 
will  be  provided  by  the  governments  of  Cambodia,  PRC,  Indonesia,  Lao  PDR,  Malaysia, 
Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam as counterpart contributions to cover local staff salaries, 
administrative support, office accommodation, equipment, and other overhead expenses. The 
TA cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  The Implementing Agencies for the TA are the ministries of finance of Cambodia, PRC, 
Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam. In particular, NSUs or 
similar agencies identified by the ministries of finance will be immediately responsible for TA 
implementation. Local staff designated to head the NSUs and similar agencies will report to their 
relevant supervisors within the ministry of finance on the implementation of the TA activities. 
The Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) of ADB will be responsible for TA execution. 
The  TA  will  finance  the  purchase  of  equipment  including  computers,  printers,  overhead 
projectors,  and  other  equipment  necessary  for  NSUs  and  similar  agencies  to  conduct

5
surveillance-related work. Any procurement will be done by OREI in coordination with the NSUs 
or similar agencies and will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. After 
completion of the TA, any procured equipment will be disposed of in accordance with Project 
Administration Instructions 5.11.  
 
12.  The TA activities will be implemented with the assistance of international and domestic 
consultants and resource persons. The scope of work and terms of reference for the consultants 
and resource persons are in Appendix 3. One to two international consultants will be engaged 
for  approximately  2  person-months  and  up  to  four  resource  persons  will  be  engaged 
intermittently  for  approximately  2  person-months.  International  consultants  and  resource 
persons  will  be  macroeconomists  with  extensive  experience  in  international  finance, 
surveillance,  EWS,  and  quantitative  methods,  and  familiar  with  the  ASEAN+3  FMP.  In 
consultation with NSUs and similar agencies, OREI will provide detailed terms of reference for  
the consultants.  
 
13.  Six to eight domestic consultants will be engaged for approximately 120 person-months 
to help train local technical staff. The domestic consultants are also expected to provide general 
technical support for surveillance-related research. The domestic consultants will be supervised 
by staff from the local NSUs and similar agencies. Selection and individual engagement of 
consultants and resource persons will follow ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. The TA will be 
carried out over 24 months starting in January 2006, and is expected to be completed by 
December 2007. 
 
14.  The  progress  of  TA  activities  will  be  monitored  through  reports  prepared  by  the 
international and domestic consultants, and through midterm and final review meetings that will 
be held with each Implementing Agency. The midterm review meetings may accommodate 
minor changes in design and execution that may be needed during implementation of the 
remainder of the TA. The final review meetings will assess the success of the TA, covering 
design and implementation, and determine whether further assistance may be required. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Economic and Financial Monitoring in Selected ASEAN+3 Countries, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Of  the  eight  countries  included  in  the  technical  assistance  (TA),  three  (Indonesia, 
Philippines, and Thailand) have already received two phases of Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
assistance  to  establish  and  operationalize  their  national  surveillance  units  (NSUs);  three 
(Cambodia,  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  [Lao  PDR],  and  Viet  Nam)  have  already 
received  one  such  phase  of  assistance;  while  two  countries  (Malaysia  and  the  People’s 
Republic of China [PRC]) are new to receiving assistance in support of their NSUs or similar 
agencies.  ADB  has  also  assisted  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN) 
Secretariat to create a data template for economic and financial indicators to assess countries’ 
and regional vulnerabilities, and to structure surveillance reports at both country and regional 
levels. Data templates and formats for national surveillance reports are available at NSUs. 
International and domestic consultants have helped NSUs establish a system for gathering data 
from different sources, completing data templates, and preparing national surveillance reports. 
 
2.  Domestic consultants in Indonesia, Philippines, and Thailand have been conducting 
technical training for NSU staff on issues related to the assessment of national economic and 
financial vulnerabilities, including usage of specific quantitative methods such as statistics and 
econometrics. NSUs in these three countries have also produced initial results using early 
warning system (EWS) models. 
 
3.  The TA will provide services from international consultants, domestic consultants, and 
resource persons. International consultants will be assisting mainly countries (Malaysia and 
PRC) that have not received any previous support under phases I and II of the TA Capacity 
Building of Ministries of Finance in Selected Developing Member Countries for the ASEAN 
Surveillance Process.1 Services from domestic consultants will in principle be offered to all eight 
countries participating in the current TA and following a specific request from the NSUs and 
similar agencies in the ministries of finance. Resource persons will be hired for short-term 
assistance  in  preparing  and  conducting  regional  technical  workshops  as  well  as  training 
programs on issues of economic and financial monitoring. 
 
A.  International Consultants (Macroeconomists) (1–2, for a total of 2 person-months) 
 
4.  International  consultants  will  be  engaged  to  conduct  training  needs  assessments, 
facilitate  design,  and  deliver  training  programs  on  surveillance-related  topics  especially  in 
Malaysia and the PRC, taking into consideration the countries’ specificities. The consultants will 
be macroeconomists with extensive experience in international finance, surveillance activities, 
EWS, economic statistics, and quantitative analysis. They will also have proven experience in 
conducting training programs for government officials. Consultant selection will consider the 
specific training needs of the involved NSUs and similar agencies. International consultants’ 
terms of reference will include, but will not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  Design and administer specific on-the-job training on issues related to economic 
and financial monitoring, directed by the needs of each country. 
(ii)  Prepare appropriate training needs assessments as well as training materials as 
requested by the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI).

(iii)  Coordinate with OREI, government officials from NSUs and similar agencies, and 
other consultants to ensure effective implementation of training activities. 
(iv)  Provide technical inputs and expert advice in national and regional workshops. 
(v)  Submit reports to OREI as requested on a case-by-case basis.  
 
B.  Domestic Consultants (Technical Assistants) (6–8, for a total of 120 person-months) 
 
5.  Domestic consultants will be engaged to assist government officials from NSUs and 
related  agencies  in  discharging  their  day-to-day  surveillance  responsibilities,  train  them  on 
administrative and technical matters, provide general technical support for surveillance-related 
research activities, as well as help design and deliver training programs and workshops on 
surveillance-related topics. The consultants will be preferably trained economists or statisticians, 
or both, with deep knowledge of international macroeconomics and finance, including technical 
matters related to economic and financial monitoring, EWS, and quantitative methods. They will 
be supervised by staff from the NSUs and similar agencies of the involved countries. The tasks 
to be performed by the consultants include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(i)  Design and implement training programs on economic and financial monitoring, 
including appropriate reference and training materials. 
(ii)  Contribute  to  daily  data  assembly,  classification,  and  processing,  including 
maintaining a specific database on surveillance-related indicators. 
(iii)  Provide expert advice and guidance to NSUs and similar agencies on financial 
vulnerabilities assessment, EWS, and other surveillance-related topics. 
(iv)  Assist in maintaining the libraries on economic and financial monitoring. 
(v)  Prepare periodical feedback and reports as requested on a case-by-case basis 
by their supervisors in the local ministries of finance and by OREI. 
 
C.  Resource Persons  
 
6.  Up to four resource persons will be engaged to facilitate the design of and deliver 
regional technical workshops and specific training on surveillance-related topics, taking into 
consideration the specific needs of each participating country and the agenda of the ASEAN+3 
Finance Ministers’ Process (FMP). Resource persons will be selected among distinguished 
macroeconomists  with  extensive  experience  in  international  finance,  surveillance  activities, 
EWS, economic statistics, and quantitative analysis. Resource persons will perform, but will not 
be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  Facilitate  the  design  of  and  deliver  regional  technical  workshops  on  issues 
related to economic and financial monitoring in support of the ASEAN+3 FMP. 
(ii)  Prepare appropriate presentation materials as requested by OREI. 
(iii)  Prepare specific comments and assessment of technical outcomes produced by 
NSUs and similar agencies on EWS and similar topics, as requested by OREI. 
(iv)  Facilitate  the  design  of  and  deliver  technical  training  on  issues  related  to 
surveillance. 
(v)  As requested on a case-by-case basis, submit reports to OREI on issues related 
to regional economic and financial monitoring and usually in conjunction with the 
organization of the regional technical workshops.
